newsitem.title: USA: INTERVIEW - Dow Jones takes aim at rivals.
newsitem.headline: INTERVIEW - Dow Jones takes aim at rivals.

text.p: Dow Jones & Co Inc said its alliance with Microsoft Corp is aimed at getting a foothold in two fast-growing markets dominated by rivals -- "buy side" financial information and electronic transaction systems.

"We want to expand into the buy side which we think will grow faster and where Bloomberg (LP) has done well," Geoffrey Moore, senior vice president of strategic communications at Dow Jones Markets, told Reuters on Tuesday.
Dow Jones said on Tuesday it plans to use Internet standards and Microsoft's software and products to help it.

Moore said the buy side -- fund managers and wealthy individuals -- was a relatively untapped market for Dow Jones Markets but was growing faster than the "sell-side" of big trading rooms which account for most revenues now.

Moore said the two firms would work together on a growing package of services compatible with standard computer equipment and software, helping bring financial information and electronic trading out of specialist environments.
These would include advanced analytics and historical databases, which its rivals already have, and dispensing with page-based information in favor of Internet standards.
No financial details were given, but Dow Jones said the initiative is part of plans to spend $650 million over four years revamping its financial information services unit, formerly called Telerate.
Moore said there would not be a joint company and neither side would be making equity investments though both companies would market the products to respective clients.

Moore said that the market for financial information services was expected to grow to $8.5 billion by the end of 1999 from $6.5 billion in 1997, and Dow Jones was planning to get 17.5 percent of it by 1999 from 14.5 percent now.
Dow Jones now has big plans to push into electronic transaction systems in which news and information company Reuters Holdings Plc is a major player.
"Transactions is a business that Reuters has been a major player in, and it is a $1 billion a year revenue business for them," said Moore.

Reuters has a share transaction system called Instinet and a foreign exchange dealing system, but Dow Jones wants to offer transactions in bonds, commodity and energy markets in addition to equities and foreign exchange.
Moore said that Dow Jones would use the transaction system company Optimark, in which it owns a minority stake, as a foundation for its electronic transaction systems.

Moore said its first offerings will be available by the end of this year, including a trading system for U.S. Treasury securities and further expansion in equities similar to its British venture with Primark Corp's Datastream.
"You will see a similar alliance in Asia fairly soon," Moore said.
Analysts say other industry players have been pushing towards open systems for some years.
Reuters now has many systems on standard personal computers, while privately-owned Bloomberg has launched a datafeed system called the Open Bloomberg to supplement its proprietary terminal.

Moore said that Dow Jones would spend $140 million to $150 million this year and more in 1998 of the four year $650 million budget. Much of this would go to upgrading internal systems to an open architecture to be ready by end 1999.
